title: Practical implementation: Interoperability in the eHealth perspective
segmentation: I would like to call Wilfred Grooman.
He will speak about Interoperability Foundation as a foundation for E Health services, so feel free to please the flow resource.
Thank you.
Ladies and gentlemen, good morning.
I learn something this morning.
I always said not dravya, but now you have to say ease dravya.
So that's the thing that I learned this morning.
Um?
The theme which I'm trying to make you warm about this.
Interoperability.
It is one of these very boring terminologies.
And so it's how can I create some enthusiasm around it?
If you don't get it, there are only two things you have to recall.
First of all.
It is extremely important is a design criteria for ICT E health solutions and the second message I would like to pass as being belonging to Microsoft.
Is that absolutely?
We are now committed to this and I would like you to give the certain.
Is that we deliver?
IDC Gardner E. Health portals.
Hospital information systems.
Care care management?
All these environments cry for police in to connect us.
It's something which customer wants and not only.
Because you would say it's this required by the EU now as part of the settlement with our organization.
No, it is because defacto.
If you saw the example about all these devices in the health sector which are interconnected from imaging systems to monitoring systems to the back office systems, it's a heater genius world.
It is a world where today ICT is not about computers.
It's about handhold devices.
It's about mobile phones.
It's about all kinds of specific devices to be interconnected in one system.
And it's also about what you saw in the examples.
The breakthrough ideas are about can we create online services?
Can we think about central patient records which are shared by the caretakers and the patients as such which we call cloud computing?
This whole environment cries for interoperability.
I think that is obviously clear.
And so the definition about it.
We all know the technical definition into connecting systems devices, but also people.
And so the layers which are technical, which are the data repositories which are the applications or which are purely the machines.
I always say and I think you concur with this.
That's done.
This is not a discussion point anymore.
Of course.
You need a CIO.
Of course you need a vendor.
To solve it, but it's not an issue.
Is even not word to discussions in Big Plenum forums about how to do realize the technological interoperability.
The challenge for the whole health sector.
And not only the health sector for the government sector.
How do you integrate organisations?
How do you integrate meaning?
The semantic layers.
How do you realize the legal frameworks that you know patient data can be shared by another entity?
That's the discussion.
So as an ID vendor, I sometimes find me a little bit alt in these forums that I've said, you know, it's it's not an ICT issue anymore.
And for that reason.
We also as Microsoft said.
The world of today is a world of interoperability and the technical vendors will work together to solve that part of the equation.
Industry associations, doctors, hospitals, projects.
Governments switch off the organizational, legal and other dimensions.
So that is just open up.
The interoperability discussion.
It is there.
It stands there.
It is important.
It is not about technology anymore.
It is about organization, legal and semantic layers.
We are committed as Microsoft to interoperability.
How can I prove that to you?
Probably you know us from some years.
But the Microsoft standing in front of you, we are committed to interoperability.
We have published openly statements about our principles.
It was part of the settlement with the EU.
In which we, for all our major products, being them the platform product's operating systems, the server to SharePoint.
Yet change.
You know the SQL Server.
Aldi's specifications to communicate with us are publicly available on the Internet.
We even have given our warranties that third parties will control that the specifications are correct when you implement them.
We made this statement that data in any of these systems can be exported in standard formats or with descriptions.
How you can export your data out of your system.
We made a statement that we will implement Standards Office 2007 supports ODF formats wherever there are standards.
We try to implement them in our products today and we engage with the community like one of these events here as kind of statements.
And so you see it in our products.
We try to really have features, you know, in the products which are open.

We tried to work with the vendors with the customers customer councils with the broader community, though even of open source developers I can show you endless portals and 80,000 projects where in fact there is some.
We have asked cooking about people working with our products.
Even open source solutions.
There is our involvement in standards committees.
We have Andreas there as a regional standards officer available here and there is a new form of licensing availability of all our intellectual property which I think makes it easy.
You know to deal with our product.
Also in the health sector we are present in most of the discussions today around health standardization, health solutions and health in effect.
No added value kind of project.
I wanted that was my second chapter.
It is important.
We are committed, and if you.
Unbelievers, please go to the Internet and you go to microsoft.com/interop and get a feel for us or just challenge us.
If we are not delivering them.
Why are we delivering that?
Because at the end, if you want to realize today a solution, being it.
Within the in health information systems or within the sector.
You need to kind of architecture.
I'm an architect architect.
How to glue this?
How do you conceptualize integration?
And for that it's going backward.
The.
For that reason, you saw it already by TAVI, and we released what we called the Connected Health framework.
It's an architecture where you say there is a dimension where you can say everything around integration services, that kind of connected health services hub.
To shield the data access layer to really offer application services as open web services, in fact are one component.
And the age I elements, the way doctors or caretakers interact with systems.
Have to be very agile, flexible to be conceived.
The way user process is are all about needs to be programmed in a very flexible way because your organization change and forget that reason.

You're going to see that in fact we have in this whole framework where partners work around solid, stable kind of solutions you know offered understand the basic connection framework and where there are infect building.
Tools building blocks to allow business processes and user process is to be delivered.
We do as an organization offer E health assets.
You heard the word Amalga.
We ourselves certainly in the US are pushing.
Health solutions we are.

A little bit trying to set the scene with health vault and you heard it this morning how you change the position by saying it is the patient who owns his data records and out of that perspective how it may be to hold health sector reorganize itself is a very interesting concept which of course needs a moderate implementation with intrance takers, insurance companies, the government in our countries like in Europe, but where at least the idea that.
The patient in the middle is, I think, really gaining traction there.
With all the kind of important experts say it's specification needed.
We have also delivered solution accelerators.
We are a platform.
Vendor you have these building blocks, operating systems, databases, web portal software, identity management software, active directories.
You know the whole exchange messaging systems which you have to integrate.
But for for the health sector.
We have done some specific accelerators.
They are like architectural guidelines.
Documented guides they are called which is shared on codeplex.com which is open source kind of portal.
Where is an example?
There's a suite of standard web services in the care sector of New Zealand.
How a number of Isvs agreed, how to do the full set lifecycle of diabeetus patient?
You know what are in fact products which can be integrated.
We have in fact worked on the cross Enterprise document sharing standard and we have solution profiles.
How to make this work?

The DOT B implementation of that one and you heard also this morning as it's such an important element in health, is that we have created a full infect development tool and guidelines and documents around the health common user interface.
How we worked at at the at the NHS in the UK and which, by the way on these websites.
You can just download 27,000 downloads of these said guidelines.
How to conceive infect the healthcare common user interface.
And so if you look at this schema, you could say messaging, since clearly on the Connect Health services help.
You could clearly say document sharing sits on a lower level on how to get access to say it structured and unstructured data.
And then you have in the HL components.
What are the libraries of software to create infected common user interface?
The president let me conclude.
I just want to say.
Fundamentally, interoperability is the foundation for E Health.
Large scale small scale you will need to deal with it.
It has become.
A design criteria of an IT system.
It should be part of an IT system to be interoperable to describe your specifications, to implement standards to have in fact everything documented that Isvs end.
Users anyway can integrate.
I want to give you the warm feeling that we are committed to this.
We are committed to standards.
Which standard?
Once somebody told me.
A standard is only as important as it market adoption.
So.

Don't question us sometimes when you say you don't implement standard H dot P-45 dot C. There is something like, I think the common sense that standards have to prove themselves in the market, and it said, and then we absolutely to our user Council.
We will implement them.
And community dialogue with vendors we have opened document initiatives for Document Interchange.
We would like to we are participants in the connect on events in the health sector.
We are in fact day today trying to get in fact under spot proof interoperability.
And last but not least this, look at us as a platform vendor.

These building components allow software vendors solution vendors to build solutions or like you just saw in the examples of the health portal, or you're going to see in some of the great examples we try to have the best Lego blocks to make it work.
And we have seen that speeding up your time to market by solution accelerators and sometimes by solutions is effect very sad.
Added value for you as end users or as designers to get going and I hope that this is convincing you a little bit that we would like to be a partner for you in this sector.
Thank you very much.
Thank you Wilfred.
